choices.text: ANA is the specific investigation for SLE
ELISA is the gold standard method for detecting ANA
Specific patterns in IF are diagnostic of the type of ANA
The specific type of ANA is best detected by ELISA

questions.text: An 18 year old female comes to you with history of arthritis for the past two months. She also gives history of hematuria. Her ESR is 140 and urine shows numerous crenated RBC with proteinuria. Suspecting SLE with nephritis you ordered for ANA test. Which of the following statements is true?
questions.solution:
This question basically deals with the tests for detecting Antinuclear Antibodies.

Antinuclear Antibodies are highly sensitive for diagnosing SLE, but not specific.

Antinuclear antibodies is not a single entity, but consists of antibodies that are directed against several different components of a cell, nucleus in particular. Hence ELISA is not the method for detecting ANA. Immunofluorescence is the preferred method.

4 different patterns of fluorescence is identified. But they are not specific for a particular antibody. So the specific antibody is identified by ELISA, if ANA is positive.

So the screening test is ANA by immunofluorescence and the test to identify the particular antibody is ELISA.

Patterns of staining in IF

Reference: Harrisons Principles Of Internal Medicine, 21st ed, Ch: 356, Pg: 2738

questions.text: A 20 year old female comes with history of arthritis, butterfly rash and fever of one month duration. Up on testing, her ANA is positive with positive anti ds DNA and Anti histone antibody. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This question deals with the different types of auto antibodies associated with SLE and their clinical significance.

Antibodies in SLE:

ANA is highly sensitive test for SLE but is very non specific. Positive in 98% of patients with SLE.

Immunoflourescence(IF) is the gold standard technique for detecting ANA. Several Antinuclear antibodies have been identified based on the pattern of fluorescence in IF.

Seeing this question, we may tend to answer it as Drug induced lupus since she has anti histone antibodies.

Anti histone antibody is seen in drug induced lupus, but it is not specific for it. Anti ds DNA is specific for SLE. Hence drug induced lupus will be negative for ds DNA. Anti histone antibodies will be seen in 70% of SLE. So the answer is SLE.

Anti Ribosomal P antibody is seen in Neuropsychiatric lupus.

Reference: Harrisons Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st ed, Ch: 356, Pg: 2738

questions.text: A 41 year old man presented with double vision and was found to have normal vertical eye movements. On left lateral gaze, there was absence of adduction of the right eye, and nystagmus in the abducting left eye. This eye movement disorder can be explained by a lesion in the:
questions.solution:
• The diagnosis is right internuclear ophthalmoplegia due to a lesion in the right medial longitudinal fasciculus.
  • The likely underlying pathology is multiple sclerosis, other causes of INO include a glioma or vascular lesion.

INO

  • Internuclear ophthalmoplegia (INO) is a disorder of conjugate lateral gazein which the affected eye shows impairment of adduction.
  • When an attempt is made to gaze contralaterally (relative to the affected eye), the affected eye adducts minimally, if at all.
  • The contralateral eye abducts, however with nystagmus.
  • Additionally, the divergence of the eyes leads to horizontal diplopia.
  • That is if the right eye is affected the patient will "see double" when looking to the left, seeing two images side-by-side. Convergence is generally preserved.

Schematic Explanation




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine 21st ed, Ch: 32, Pg: 230

questions.text:
A 51 year old woman with long standing rheumatoid arthritis. She presents with increasing malaise. Investigations showed:
Hb 7.5 g/dl
Neutrophil count 1.2 x 10^9/L
Platelet count 90 x 10^9/L
Her ESR was 120 mm/hr and CRP 145 mg/dl
On examination, she was pale and had palpable splenomegaly.
The most likely cause of her haematologic abnormalities is:
questions.solution:
Felty's syndrome is defined by the clinical triad of neutropenia, splenomegaly, and nodular RA.

It is seen in <1% of patients, although its incidence appears to be declining due to early and aggressive treatment.

It typically occurs in the late stages of severe RA.

D/D: T-cell large granular lymphocyte leukemia (T-LGL) is characterized by a chronic, indolent clonal growth of LGL cells, leading to neutropenia and splenomegaly. But, T-LGL may develop early in the course of RA.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Ch:358, Pg:2753

questions.text: Which cell is primarily involved in causing structural damage to joints in RA?
questions.solution:
Osteoclasts are the cells that are ultimately responsible for the structural damage in RA.

The chief pathology of RA is bone not only bone destruction, but also decreased bone formation.

The first cells that are activated are CD4 + T cells. Macrophages are the chief inflammatory cells involved. But the bone damage is mediated by activated osteoclasts.

Bone erosions: The damage is typically located at the regions where the synovium is inserted to the periosteal surface at the edge of bone, at the rim of the articular cartilage. This also explains the development of bone erosions at the radial aspect of the MCP.

Juxtra-articular osteopenia is another pathology that is seen in the adjacent bone due to inflammation of marrow. It results in substantial thinning of bone trabeculae.

TNFα inhibits bone formation by inhibiting osteoblasts.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st ed, Ch: 358, Pg: 2756-2757

questions.text: A 52 year old patient with active rheumatoid arthritis has continued symptoms despite treatment with optimal dose methotrexate. She is having pain in multiple joints. What is the most appropriate next treatment?
questions.solution:
For patients who are not controlled on Methotrexate, the therapy has to be stepped up aggressively.

The preferred therapy is Methotrexate with biologicals.

The current regimen is to start early aggressive therapy and to add second agent within 3 to 6 months.

Triple therapy is Methotrexate with HCQ and Sulfasalazine, which is preferred in mild disease.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Ch:358, Pg:2764

questions.text: A 49 year old female is having history of Raynaud's phenomenon for the last 6 years. She has noticed skin tightening for the last one year. On examination, you pinched the skin of her chest and found that it was normal. Which of the following complication is she least likely to develop?
questions.solution:
The patient in the given question has long standing history of Raynaud's phenomenon with sparing of the trunk. So the diagnosis is Limited Cutaneous Scleroderma.

The associations of limited cutaneous scleroderma are:

CREST syndrome

Isolated PAH

Less frequent associations are:

Primary Biliary Cirrhosis

Sjogren's syndrome

Hypothyroidism

Renal involvement and renal crisis are very rare in limited cutaneous disease

The antibody associated is anti-centromere antibody

Difference between Limited Cutaneous and Diffuse cutaneous Systemic Sclerosis

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Ed, Ch: 360, Pg: 2771, 2778

questions.text: A 32 year old woman has a 3 month history of arthralgia joint pain and early morning stiffness. There is swelling of the distal interphalangeal joints of the ring fingers of the hand. The wrist on the right and ankles are swollen as well. Onycholysis was noted on the nails. Her serum inflammatory markers are raised. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The presence of joint pains and early morning stiffness points towards an inflammatory arthritis. The patient in the given question is suffering from an asymmetric oligoarthritis, with involvement of DIP, which rules out RA.

The sparing of large proximal joints and the age of the patient speaks against a Polymyalgia rheumatica.

There are no other indicators to suggest a chronic gout, like tophi.

An asymmetric oligoarthritis with onycholysis points to the diagnosis of Psoriatic Arthritis.

Wright and Moll described five patterns of Psoriatic Arthritis:

  1. arthritis of the DIP joints
  2. asymmetric oligoarthritis
  3. symmetric polyarthritis similar to RA
  4. axial involvement (spine and sacroiliac joints)
  5. arthritis mutilans, a highly destructive form of the disease.

A simpler scheme in recent use contains three patterns: oligoarthritis, polyarthritis, and axial arthritis.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st ed, Ch: 362, Pg: 2799

questions.text: The hand X ray of a patient with chronic arthritis is given. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The figure shows the typical "Pencil in cup" deformity seen in Psoriatic Arthritis.

It is where narrowed end of metacarpal or phalanx get inserted into the expanded adjacent bone.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st ed, Ch: 362, Pg: 2800

questions.text: A 71-year-old man develops weakness of the shoulders and around the hips over a 6-month period. He has also noticed weak finger flexors. He complained of difficulty swallowing liquids. There is no other significant past medical history. He smokes 15 cigarettes a day and drinks a bottle of wine at the weekend. A creatinine kinase level comes back at 120 U/l.A muscle biopsy sample shows myopathic changes. There are also inflammatory. infiltrates and intracytoplasmic vacuoles present. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Clinical points towards diagnosis of IBM:

  • Age over 50 years
  • Weakness of finger flexors
  • This is an inflammatory condition affecting patients over the age of 50.
  • Proximal muscles in the upper and lower limbs, and finger flexors are predominantly involved.
  • The onset of muscle weakness in IBM is generally gradual (over months or years).
  • Dysphagia is common, occurring in 40-66% of patients. IBM occurs more frequently in men than women. CK may be normal.
  • A muscle biopsy usually shows intracytoplasmic inclusions and also inflammatory infiltrates.
  • Granular lymphocytic leukemia/ lymphocytosis, sarcoidosis, sicca or Sjögren's syndrome are the conditions that may be associated.

Thigh atrophy seen in inclusion body myositis

Inclusion bodies and inflammatory infiltrates(arrows)

Reference: Harrison's principles of Internal Medicine, 21st ed, Ch: 365, Pg: 2823

questions.text: A 41 year old man complains of pain in the right eye, which has worsened over the last few days. On examination, he had a ptosis of the right eye. He also had a weakness of superior upgaze of the right eye and loss of accommodation reflex, with a dilated pupil. Which of the following is likely?
questions.solution:
Complete Ptosis of the right eye with loss of accommodation reflex indicates a 3rd nerve palsy.

  • Patients with painful, isolated third nerve palsy with pupillary involvement is most likely due to a posterior communicating artery aneurysm. Other causes of mononeuritis multiplex (diabetes, vasculitis, syphilis), can also cause a third nerve palsy, but seldom are painful.

Arteriogram - Lateral view showing a posterior

communicating artery aneurysm.

Option A: Myasthenia gravis would cause diurnal symptoms of ptosis and diplopia which would occur a few hours after waking up.

Option B: Neurosyphilis would cause an Argyll Robertson Pupil which is characterized by absent pupillary reflex with a preserved accommodation reflex. It occurs due to lesion in the pretectal region

Option C: Multiple sclerosis would cause an internuclear ophthalmoplegia which causes a loss of adduction of ipsilateral eye on abduction of contralateral eye. It occurs due to lesion in medial longitudinal fasciculus

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st ed, Ch: 429, Pg: 3355

questions.text: A 54 year old man presents with speech difficulty. He has difficulty with word identification and repetition. He is able to pick out correct objects when instructed to do so and is not confused. Where is the lesion?
questions.solution:
This patient is definitely having an aphasia, since he has difficulty in word identification(anomia). his comprehension is normal hence is Wenicke's area is normal. So he is likely suffering from Broca's Aphasia.

A patient with Wernicke's Aphasia may look confused to the examiner because of the neologisms and increased word output. Repetition will be lost in all aphasias except, transcortical motor aphasia, transcortical sensory aphasia, pure anomia and pure alexia.

  • Broca's Area (Inferior frontal lobe) damage causes impaired fluency, intact comprehension, impaired repetition [expressive dysphasia].
  • Wernicke's Area (posterior, superior temporal lobe) damage causes normal fluency, impaired comprehension, impaired repetition [receptive dysphasia].

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Chapter: 30, page number:196

questions.text: A 33-year-old female was admitted to the hospital after experiencing a sudden and severe episode of headache. No precipitating factor was identified. Except for mild neck stiffness, general physical and neurological examinations were unremarkable. On admission, a computed tomography (CT) scan showed a thin collection of blood on the right sylvian cistern, establishing the diagnosis of subarachnoid haemorrhage. The admitting doctor is considering further management. Which of the Following medications have been shown to decrease the incidence of cerebral infarction in patients with subarachnoid haemorrhage?
questions.solution:
The medical management of SAH focuses on protecting the air way, managing blood pressure before and after aneurysm treatment, preventing rebleeding prior to treatment, managing vasospasm and Delayed Cerebral Ischemia(DCI), treating hydrocephalus, treating hyponatremia, limiting secondary brain insults, and preventing pulmonary embolus (PE).

DCI remains the leading cause of morbidity and mortality following aneurysmal SAH. Treatment with the calcium channel antagonist nimodipine (60 mg PO every 4 h) improves outcome, perhaps by preventing ischemic injury rather than reducing the risk of vasospasm.

Osmotic agents can worsen the cerebral perfusion and can worsen ischemia and hence should be given only to those with features of raised ICP.

Vasopressors and hydration also helps to prevent cerebral ischemia.

Steroids may be used to reduce head and neck pain caused by blood in the sub arachnoid space. It does not reduce cerebral ischemia and is hence not routinely recommended.

So the most appropriate answer is Nimodipine

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st ed, Ch: 429, Pg: 3355

questions.text: A 77 year old man has dysphasia and left sided arm weakness. He is known to have hypertension, asthma and rheumatoid arthritis. In addition he suffered from cluster headaches. He smokes 20 cigarettes a day. On examination, he has some weakness of the left hand. Visual fields, speech and sensation are normal. Blood pressure is 190/90 mmHg. Which of the Following is most likely?
questions.solution:
The history suggests the dysarthria-clumsy hand syndrome, one of the classic lacunar syndromes that are strokes in the subcortical regions (or brain stem) secondary to small vessel disease. The usual site of damage in the dysarthria-clumsy hand syndrome is the internal capsule or pons.

  • Lacunar infarcts are small lesions (usually less than 1.5 cm in diameter) that occur in the distribution of short penetrating arterioles in the basal ganglia, pons, cerebellum, internal capsule, thalamus and, less commonly, the deep cerebral white matter.
  • Lacunar infarcts are associated with poorly controlled hypertension or diabetes and have been found in several clinical syndromes, including :
    1. contralateral pure motor hemiparesis
    2. Contralateral pure hemisensory deficit
    3. ipsilateral ataxia with hemiparesis
    4. dysarthria clumsy hand syndrome

The neurologic deficit may progress over 24-36 hours before stabilizing.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st ed, Ch: 427, Ch: 3341

questions.text: A patient presents with a new onset headache. Which of the following makes the diagnosis of migraine least likely?
questions.solution:
This question basically deals with two major concepts:

  1. Primary Vs secondary headache
  2. New onset headache

Primary headache is where the headache is not associated with any structural problems of the head, where as secondary headache occurs as a result of structural diseases of the head.

New onset headache is new and severe headache occurring in a patient. New onset headache are mostly due to secondary causes. The presence of the following makes the possibility of secondary head ache more:

  1. Age of onset >55 years
  2. Worst ever headache
  3. Sudden onset
  4. Vomiting preceding headache
  5. Focal neurological deficits including papilledema
  6. Associated systemic illness
  7. Fever
  8. Headache worsened on bending, lifting, coughing etc
  9. Early morning heads ache or headache disturbing sleep
  10. Pain associated with tenderness of scalp

So in the above question, our patient has a new onset headache and the presence of papilledema points towards a secondary headache than migraine. Photophobia, unilateral headache and throbbing pain can occur in primary or secondary headache.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st ed, Ch: 16 Pg:112-113

questions.text: A 42-year-old man has a 5-year history of recurrent right sided headaches which last for 2 hours. There is a pattern of daily occurrence for 2 to 3 weeks, followed by a month or so without headaches. The headaches were described as "explosive" and were graded 9 to 10 in severity on a visual analogue scale of 1 to 10. The quality of the head pain was reported to be throbbing, sharp, shooting, as well as aching. The pain was localized around the right eye, behind the right ear, and in the occipital region. There are no associated visual symptoms, but occasionally flushing is associated. He gets these headaches frequently during the winter. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This question is the classical description of a Cluster Headache.

  • Bouts of frequent attacks, known as cluster periods, can last from weeks to months, usually followed by remission periods when the headaches stop. During remission, no headaches occur for months and sometimes even years.

Common signs and symptoms

  • Pain:
    • Usually retro-orbital
    • Deep, excruciating in intensity
    • Non fluctuating
    • And explosive.
  • Ipsilateral cranial parasympathetic activation:
    • Conjunctival injection
    • Lacrimation
    • Aural fullness
    • Rhinorrhoea or nasal congestion
  • Cranial sympathetic dysfunction such as ptosis

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st ed, Ch: 430, Pg: 3366

choices.text: Cluster headache is more common in males than in females
Indomethacin is an effective treatment modality
Non invasive vagal stimulation is an approved abortive therapy of cluster head ache

questions.text: A 40 year old male presents with history of recurrent episodes of left retroorbital pain. It occurs one or two times in a day and lasts for around 1 or two hours. During the episodes the patient seems agitated and is associated with lacrimation. He gets such attacks for around 1 or two months after which he remains asymptomatic, just to get recurrence of such attacks in the future. Which of the following statements is false
questions.solution:
This question deals with the clinical features of Cluster head ache. Cluster head ache has a male preponderance among the Trigeminal Autonomic Cephalagias. The other TACs are Paroxysmal Hemicrania and SUNCT/SUNA occur in equal frequency in males and females.

Cluster head ache has a definite association with alcohol intake, whereas, the other two does not have any association.

Among the TACs Paroxysmal Hemicrania is the only head ache having a responsiveness to Indomethacin.

Treatment of Cluster Head ache:

  • Acute attack:
    • Respond well to oxygen inhalation as 100% oxygen at 10-15 L/min for 15-20 minutes.
    • Sumatriptan 6 mg SC is rapid in onset and will usually shorten an attack to 10-15 min.
    • Sumatriptan (20 mg) and zolmitriptan (5 mg) nasal sprays are both effective in acute cluster headache, offering a useful option for patients who may not wish to self-inject daily.
    • Oral sumatriptan is not effective for prevention or for acute treatment of cluster headache.
  • Neurostimulation therapy:
    • When medical therapies fail in chronic cluster headache, neurostimulation strategies can be employed.
    • Deep-brain stimulation of the region of the posterior hypothalamic gray matter has proven successful in a substantial proportion of patients.
    • Non-invasive vagal nerve stimulation is FDA approved using three 2-min stimulation cycles applied consecutively at the onset of headache on the side of pain. This may be repeated after 9 minutes

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st ed, Ch: 430, Pg: 3366-3367

choices.text: Since the episodes lasts only for around 3 weeks, steroids are a good option for preventive therapy
Verapamil is the first line treatment for episodes that lasts longer
Lithium is a drug that is of proven benefit in preventing the episodes of this head ache
CGRP monoclonal antibody is useful in chronic cluster head ache

questions.text: A 30 year old male comes to you with history of recurrent retro orbital pains that occurs once or twice in a day, each lasting for around an hour, associated with ipsilateral lacrimation. He has had similar episodes before which occurred for a period of 1week, after which he remains asymptomatic for around 6-8 months. Which of the following statements is false regarding the preventive therapy of the above condition?
questions.solution:
The patient in the question suffers from cluster head ache. The bouts or episodes occur for a very short period of 1 weeks. The preventive therapy of cluster head ache depends up on the duration of bouts.

For shorter bouts the drugs that are approved are:

  1. Prednisolone
  2. CGRP monoclonal antibody Galcanezumab
  3. Great Occipital nerve injection with lignocaine or steroids
  4. Verapamil

For bouts that are longer, the drugs that are approved are

  1. Verapamil 160-960mg/day
  2. Lithium 400-800mg/day
  3. Non invasive vagal stimulation
  4. Deep brain stimulation
  5. Melatonin, Topiramate and Gabapentin are of unproven benefits

So among the options, the CGRP monoclonal antibody is useful not for chronic cluster head ache or longer bouts, but for shorter bouts of head ache.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st ed, Ch: 430, Pg: 3367

questions.text: A 19-year old man has difficulty walking. He has had problems with vision which were difficult to correct with glasses. On examination, there is nystagmus and pallor of the optic discs. He has dysarthria and intention tremors. There are absent reflexes in the knees and ankles. Plantars are equivocal. Pes cavus was noted. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Friedreich's Ataxia is inherited autosomal recessively. Patients may have cardiomyopathy and diabetes. Neurological abnormalities include optic atrophy and retinitis pigmentosa, nystagmus, cerebellar disease and signs, loss of dorsal column sensation and weakness. Pes cavus (high arched feet) is usually present.

Spinocerebellar ataxia is an autosomal dominant ataxia. The SCA7 is associated with blue yellow colour blindness.

Wilson's disease presents with parkinsonian features and has a KF ring in the lens and is not associated with pes cavus.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page Number-3429.

questions.text: A 52 year old man presents with a history of slowly progressive, abnormal movements of his body. On examination there are jerky, semi-purposive movements involving the entire body and abnormal tongue movements. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Huntington's disease is a genetic disorder characterized by abnormal, involuntary movements known as chorea. These movements can involve the entire body and often affect the face, resulting in abnormal tongue movements. The condition typically progresses slowly and is associated with neurological and cognitive symptoms. It is an autosomal dominant genetic disorder caused by a mutation in the HTT gene.
  • There are many causes of chorea.
    • Inherited- Ataxia-telangiectasia, Huntington disease, Wilson disease.
    • Drugs - Anticonvulsants (eg, phenytoin, carbamazepine, phenobarbital), Antidopaminergic agents (eg, phenothiazines, haloperidol, metoclopramide)
    • Behcet disease, antiphospholipid antibody syndrome, Bacterial endocarditis, Herpes simplex encephalitis, Lyme disease.

The other options can be ruled out as follows:

  • A) Parkinson's disease: Parkinson's disease primarily presents with symptoms such as resting tremors, bradykinesia (slowness of movement), rigidity, and postural instability, which are different from the choreiform (chorea-like) movements seen in Huntington's disease.
  • B) Motor neuron disease: Motor neuron disease, such as amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS), typically presents with muscle weakness, muscle atrophy, and spasticity rather than the choreiform movements seen in this case.
  • C) Frontal lobe tumor: Frontal lobe tumors may present with various neurological symptoms, but the combination of jerky, semi-purposive movements affecting the entire body and abnormal tongue movements is not characteristic of frontal lobe tumors.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Ed, Ch: 436, Pg: 3405

questions.text:
A 74-year-old man is diagnosed with a Lewy body dementia.
Which one of the following drugs would be contraindicated for this patient?
questions.solution:
Patients with DLB are sensitive to Dopeminergic agonists and anticholinergics that worsen their symptoms. Hence Dopeminergic agonists should be used with careful titration of the dose and addition of cholinesterase Inhibitors.

They are also sensitive to typical antipsychotics that causes Neurolept Malignant Syndrome.

The drug absolutely contra indicated is Haloperidol, among the options.

Management of DLB includes:

Cholinestrase inhibitors like Rivastigmine.

Pimavanserin is an atypical antipsychotic approved for treatment of Psychosis.

Low dose clozapine can also be used.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st ed, Ch: 434, Pg: 3386

questions.text: A 71 year old man has a 2 month history of progressive weakness in his legs. He has weakness in the hip and knee distribution. Knee and ankle reflexes are brisk. Plantars are upgoing bilaterally. He has sensory loss from legs upwards towards the T5 level. Which one of the Following is a likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• A meningioma involving high in the spinal cord (thoracic region) can cause a T5 level. The rest are all causes of spastic paraparesis but are unlikely to cause a sensory level on clinical examination.
  • Friedrichs ataxia presents with prominent cerebellar signs along with upper motor neuron features due to degeneration of cerebellum, spinocerebellar and corticospinal tracts
  • Subacute combined degeneration is a neurological complication of B12 deficiency which has an absent ankle reflex due to a concomitant neuropathy
  • Hereditary (familial) spastic paraparesis is a group of rare hereditary disorders that cause gradual weakness with muscle spasms (spastic weakness) in the legs. It occurs due to motor neuron dysfunction and will not cause a sensory level as seen in this case.

Reference:Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Ed, Ch: 442, Pg: 3447

questions.text: A 45-year-old man has developed weakness over the past 3 weeks which has affected his walking. He has no significant past medical history. On examination, he had decreased sensation peripherally in the legs and also flaccid reflexes in the ankles. A CT of the head was normal and lumbar puncture was done.Results were:Protein 0.75(<0.43 g/l)Glucose 4 (3.3 to 4.4 mmol/l)Lymphocytes 7 (< 5/mm3) What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The dissociation between a high CSF protein, normal glucose and a lack of CSF cellular response in a person with an acute or subacute polyneuropathy is diagnostic of Guillain-Barre syndrome. In GBS, CSF protein is elevated in most patients after the second or third week of illness. The gamma globulin fraction is usually raised. Cells, usually monocytes, are found in 20% of cases.

Guillain-Barre syndrome (GBS): (Post-infectious polyradiculoneuropathy) -

  • Immune-mediated demyelination of the peripheral nervous system often triggered by an infection such as viral (CMV), viral pneumonia or bacterial (classically Campylobacter jejuni).

Pathogenesis - Anti GM1 antibodies positive in 25% of cases.

Clinical features -

  • The characteristic features of GBS is progressive symmetric ascending weakness.
  • No sensory loss
  • Areflexia - All tendon reflexes are absent and the plantar responses were flexor.
  • Cranial nerve involvement e.g., diplopia
  • Autonomic dysfunction: e.g., urinary retention and postural hypotension & tachycardia.
  • Diaphragmatic weakness occurs in 30% of patients.

Management -

  • IVIG (IV immunoglobulins) or plasmapheresis.
  • Regular monitoring of FVC (Forced vital capacity) to access respiratory function.

Poliomyelitis is a disease that occurs during childhood and has some disability. History of vaccine not taken may be there.

Tuberculous meningitis presents with acute history of fever, headache, altered sensorium, convulsions etc. History of TB foci may be there elsewhere in the body.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine 21st ed, Ch:447, Pg: 3501-3504

choices.text: Paired CSF and serum for oligoclonal bands

questions.text:
A 35 year old man has difficulty with his vision. On examination he has impaired adduction of the right eye looking left. The left eye has jerky nystagmus.
Which investigation is most likely to yield a diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The clinical scenario is internuclear ophthalmoplegia.
  • This is most commonly seen in multiple sclerosis. MRI of the brain and CSF are the best diagnostic tests. In this scenario the lesion is in the right medial longitudinal fasciculus.

Internuclear ophthalmoplegia - patient looking to the left

MR imaging of the brain showed multiple abnormal high signals on T2WI involving bilateral deep white matter, corpus callosum, occipital periventricular regions, and periaqueductal regions of the pons and medulla

Diagnostic tools in MS:

MRI

  • Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain and spine may show areas of demyelination (lesions or plaques).
  • Gadolinium can be administered intravenously as a contrast agent to highlight active plaques and, by elimination, demonstrate the existence of historical lesions not associated with symptoms at the moment of the evaluation.
  • Central vein signs (CVS) have been proposed as a good indicator of MS in comparison with other conditions causing white lesions.
  • Brain atrophy is seen as an indicator of MS.

Cerebrospinal fluid

  • Testing of cerebrospinal fluid obtained from a lumbar puncture can provide evidence of chronic inflammation in the central nervous system.
  • The cerebrospinal fluid is tested for oligoclonal bands of IgG on electrophoresis, which are inflammation markers found in 75-85% of people with MS.

Evoked potential

Visual- and sensory-evoked potential tests measure brain responses; the nervous system in MS may respond less actively to stimulation of the optic nerve and sensory nerves due to demyelination of such pathways

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st ed, Ch:444, Pg: 3466

questions.text: A 38 year old teacher has a right sided headache and blurring of her vision in the right eye. She has previously had an episode of optic neuritis 3 years beforehand, in the right eye. On examination, there was a right afferent pupillary defect and pale optic disc. There was weakness of the facial muscles on the right. Tone and reflexes were brisk on the right with power of 3/5 in the arm and the leg. She was apyrexial. MRI of the brain reveals a 4 cm left temporo-parietal mass, which was incompletely ring enhancing. There were also two small white matter lesions also visible in the frontal area. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient gives a history of optic neuritis in the past, now with a second episode of ON as evidenced by the RAPD. She now presents with weakness of the right side of the body and face. The presence of optic neuritis with pyramidal type weakness should prompt us to think about demyelinating diseases like MS, NMO spectral disorders, and MOG antibody associated demyelinating disease. ADEM is also a demyelinating disease but is monophasic and does not present with recurrence.

So in the MRI we are expecting findings of demyelination. The two small white matter lesions in MRI may be demyelinating patches, but how to explain the 4 cm temperoparietal mass ?

So, there are variants of MS that can present as space occupying lesions with incomplete or concentric ring enhancement, as shown below. It is called the Balo's Concentric sclerosis.

So the presence of mass lesions with incomplete contrast enhancement is also possible in MS.

CNS lymphoma presents with complete ring enhancement and is seen in the context of HIV.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine , 21st ed, Ch:444, Pg: 3474
